AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya: defendant claiming ineffective assistance of counsel due to incorrect application of sentencing guidelines, with a base offense level calculated under the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Nancy F. Atlas: judge who concludes that jurists of reason would not debate whether the movant has stated a valid claim or whether any procedural ruling in this case was correct, resulting in the denial of a certificate of appealability
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States of America: plaintiff in the case, whose motions to dismiss and expand the record were granted by Nancy F. Atlas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.illegal aliens: individuals being smuggled within the United States for commercial advantage and private financial gain, involved in a hostage-taking offense with between six and twenty-four aliens, held against their will for ransom demand
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.foreign nationals: persons held for ransom and against their will, involved in an illegal alien smuggling venture
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Federal Grand Jury: grand jury that may deny a certificate of appealability, sua sponte, without requiring further briefing or argument
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Presentence Report: report prepared for determining punishment under the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual, including calculations of total offense level based on the most serious count among the group, with objections raised by counsel
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.PSR: abbreviation for Presentence Report, used in determining sentence based on the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Guidelines Manu: manual used to determine sentences, with different editions having distinct implications for base offense levels and overall sentencing severity, including amendments that affect the calculation of base offense levels
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.The United States Court of Appeals for t: court that hears appeals, including those related to illegal alien smuggling ventures, requiring a certificate of appealability before proceeding
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States Supreme Court: highest court in the United States, which could have been appealed to regarding Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's case, concerning issues such as ex post facto laws and ineffective assistance of counsel, with relevant decisions impacting the case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Adrian Almaguer: attorney for Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya, who raised an objection to the base offense level in the Presentence Report but later acknowledged using an incorrect version of the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States of America Constitutio: Document outlining the fundamental laws and principles of the United States, including prohibitions on ex post facto laws
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.ex post facto Law: law that prohibits applying a more onerous penalty than was in effect at the time of the offense
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States Congress: Legislative body of the United States, prohibited from enacting ex post facto laws
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.illegal alien smuggling venture: a smuggling operation involving illegal aliens, subject to specific sentencing guidelines and laws
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's motion: motion filed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, requiring a certificate of appealability to proceed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Pe: federal law governing appeals in certain cases, including those related to illegal alien smuggling ventures, with specific requirements for certificates of appealability
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.certificate of appealability: document required for an appeal to proceed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, which will not issue unless the petitioner makes a substantial showing of the denial of a constitutional right
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.joint appeal of Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelay: appeal filed by Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya regarding his conviction and sentence for an illegal alien smuggling venture, focusing on the application of sentencing guidelines and claims of ineffective assistance of counsel, with a denied certificate of appealability
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court that assesses constitutional claims and makes procedural rulings, subject to review by higher courts, with jurisdiction over Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's case and the denial of his motion for relief
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the aliens: individuals being smuggled within the United States for commercial advantage and private financial gain, involved in a hostage-taking offense with between six and twenty-four aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's claims: claims made by Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya regarding his sentence calculation under the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual and ineffective assistance of counsel
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Probation Department: department that advised on the relevant Guideline found in the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual and its amendment affecting the base offense level calculation
